qas.question: What time period did the colonialism of the Sahara begin?
What country conquered the Algiers from the Ottomans in   1830?
During what time were good moved through more modern   means?
When did the Ottomans conquer France?
What caused trans-Saharan trade to take off in the 20th century?

plausible_answers.text: present-day Algeria, Chad, Mali then French Sudan including Timbuktu, Mauritania, Morocco (1912), Niger, and Tunisia (1881)

qas.question: What area of the regency of Algiers was not under French control?
When did France relinquish control of Morocco?
What year did France conquer Niger?

context: European colonialism in the Sahara began in the <a0_0>19th century<a0_0/>. <a1_0>France<a1_0/> conquered the regency of Algiers from the Ottomans in <b3_0>1830<b3_0/>, and French rule spread south from Algeria and eastwards from Senegal into the upper Niger to include <b5_0>present-day Algeria, Chad, Mali then French Sudan including Timbuktu, Mauritania, Morocco (<b6_0>1912<b6_0/>), Niger, and Tunisia (<b7_0>1881<b7_0/>)<b5_0/>. By the beginning of the <a2_0>20th century<a2_0/>, the trans-Saharan trade had clearly declined because goods were moved through <b4_0>more modern and efficient means<b4_0/>, such as airplanes, rather than across the desert.
